definitions: engage in sexual intercourse in a rough or casual manner
run after and catch a fly ball during fielding practice in baseball
examples: They decided to shag after meeting at the nightclub
The couple would often shag in their university dormitory
The outfielders shagged fly balls for thirty minutes before the game
Young players love to shag balls during batting practice sessions

definitions: pretend to be or have something falsely in order to deceive others
examples: He tried to sham illness to avoid going to work
The company shammed their financial success to attract more investors

definitions: wash hair or carpet with a special cleaning liquid designed for that purpose
examples: She shampoos her hair every other day for healthy locks
The hotel staff shampooed all the carpets before the grand opening

definitions: trick or force someone into doing something they did not intend to do
examples: The captain tried to shanghai sailors from the local tavern
She felt shanghaied into organizing the entire company party alone

definitions: hit a golf ball with the hosel causing it to fly sharply right
examples: He shanked his approach shot into the water hazard
Even professional golfers occasionally shank the ball under pressure

definitions: make the edge or point of something more acute by grinding or honing
make mental faculties or skills more acute through practice or concentration
examples: He sharpened the kitchen knives before preparing the elaborate dinner
The carpenter sharpens his chisels every morning before starting work
Reading challenging books helps sharpen your critical thinking skills daily
The debate team sharpened their arguments before the national championship

definitions: break suddenly into many small pieces due to impact or pressure
destroy completely someone's confidence hopes or beliefs causing severe emotional damage
examples: The wine glass shattered when it hit the marble floor
A baseball shattered the living room window during practice
The rejection letter shattered her dreams of attending medical school
His harsh criticism shattered the young artist's confidence completely

definitions: remove hair from face or body using a razor or similar tool
reduce something by a small amount especially time or cost
examples: He shaves his beard every morning before heading to work
She decided to shave her legs before going to the beach
The runner shaved two seconds off her personal best time
The company shaved costs by switching to cheaper suppliers

definitions: cut wool from sheep or cut something with large scissors or shears
break or cause to break from stress typically along a plane
examples: Farmers shear their sheep twice a year for wool production
The hairdresser sheared off her long locks for charity
The metal bolt sheared under the extreme weight and pressure
Strong winds can shear branches from trees during severe storms

definitions: lose hair leaves or skin naturally as part of growth or seasons
get rid of something unwanted or unnecessary from your life or possessions
store things in a small simple building used for storage or shelter
examples: Dogs shed their winter coat as warmer weather approaches
The maple trees shed their colorful leaves every autumn
She decided to shed negative thoughts and embrace positivity
The company shed hundreds of jobs during the economic downturn
He keeps his gardening tools organized in the backyard shed
They shed old furniture in the garage to make space

definitions: apply a resinous substance as a protective coating to wood or other surfaces
defeat someone decisively in a game competition or conflict
examples: The furniture maker shellacked the antique table to restore its shine
You should shellac wooden floors to protect them from moisture damage
Our basketball team shellacked the visitors by forty points last night
The defending champion shellacked all challengers in the tournament finals

definitions: guide or direct a group of people in a protective and caring manner
examples: The teacher shepherded the young students through the busy museum
The tour guide shepherded tourists away from the dangerous cliff edge

definitions: shine with a soft wavering light that seems to move slightly
examples: The lake shimmered beautifully under the bright summer moonlight
Her sequined dress shimmered as she danced across the ballroom floor

definitions: shake the body or hips in a dancing movement often rhythmically
shake or vibrate abnormally especially of vehicle wheels or mechanical parts
examples: The dancers shimmied to the upbeat jazz music all night
She learned to shimmy during her belly dancing classes
The car's front wheels shimmy when driving over sixty miles per hour
The washing machine shimmies across the floor during the spin cycle

definitions: climb quickly up or down something by gripping with arms and legs
examples: The children love to shin up trees in the backyard
He had to shin down the drainpipe to escape the burning building

definitions: cover a roof or wall with overlapping rows of flat rectangular tiles
examples: They hired contractors to shingle their house before winter arrived
The roofers will shingle the entire church roof next week

definitions: cause a ship to be destroyed by sinking or running aground
ruin or destroy plans hopes or ventures causing complete failure
examples: The storm shipwrecked three vessels off the rocky coastline
Pirates would deliberately shipwreck merchant ships to steal their cargo
Poor planning shipwrecked their dreams of starting a restaurant
One bad decision can shipwreck years of hard work

definitions: avoid or neglect a duty or responsibility through laziness or cowardice
examples: He always shirks his household chores leaving them for others
Employees who shirk their duties face disciplinary action from management

definitions: shake slightly and uncontrollably from being cold frightened or excited
examples: She began to shiver in the freezing winter wind
The scary movie made the children shiver with fear and excitement

definitions: form into a large group especially of fish swimming together in shallow water
examples: The fish shoal near the coral reef for protection from predators
Sardines shoal in massive numbers during their annual migration

definitions: make a person or animal go away by waving arms or making sounds
examples: She had to shoo the pigeons away from her lunch
The farmer shooed the chickens back into their coop

definitions: make something smaller in length distance or duration than it was before
examples: The tailor will shorten these pants to fit perfectly
Bad weather forced them to shorten their vacation by two days

definitions: select a small number of candidates from a larger group for final consideration
examples: The committee shortlisted five applicants for the director position
They shortlisted three venues for their wedding reception next summer

definitions: move coal snow sand or other material using a broad scoop tool
eat food quickly and in large amounts without proper manners
examples: He shoveled snow from the driveway for two hours
Workers shoveled coal into the furnace all day long
The hungry teenager shoveled food into his mouth at dinner
Stop shoveling your breakfast and chew your food properly

definitions: tear or cut something into thin strips or small pieces
play electric guitar with extremely fast and skillful technique
examples: She needs to shred these confidential documents before disposal
The recipe says to shred the cheese before adding it
The guitarist can shred amazing solos during live performances
He learned to shred by practicing scales eight hours daily

definitions: utter a high-pitched piercing sound or cry expressing fear excitement or pain
examples: The children shrieked with delight on the roller coaster
She shrieked when she saw the mouse run across the floor

definitions: make a high-pitched and piercing sound that is unpleasant to hear
examples: The referee's whistle shrilled across the soccer field
The smoke alarm shrilled loudly waking everyone in the house

definitions: wrap or cover a body completely especially for burial or protection
cover or hide something making it difficult to see or understand
examples: They shrouded the body in white cloth according to tradition
Fog shrouded the mountain peaks throughout the morning
Mystery shrouds the circumstances of his sudden disappearance
The company shrouded their new product plans in complete secrecy

definitions: shake convulsively typically as a result of fear disgust or cold
shake or vibrate violently especially of machines or structures under stress
examples: She shuddered at the thought of eating raw oysters
He shuddered with cold in the unheated waiting room
The old building shuddered when heavy trucks passed by
The airplane shuddered through severe turbulence over the mountains

definitions: walk without lifting feet properly dragging them along the ground
mix playing cards by sliding them over each other randomly
rearrange the order or position of things in a group or system
examples: The elderly man shuffled slowly down the hospital corridor
Don't shuffle your feet when you walk into the interview
The dealer shuffled the cards before starting the poker game
Always shuffle the deck thoroughly to ensure fair play
The manager shuffled staff assignments to improve team productivity
She shuffled papers on her desk looking for the report

definitions: persistently avoid reject or ignore someone or something considered undesirable
examples: The village shunned him after he broke their sacred traditions
She decided to shun social media for better mental health

definitions: move a train or railway car to a different track
move someone or something to a different place often to avoid dealing with them
examples: Railway workers shunted the freight cars onto the siding
The conductor shunted our train to platform three
The hospital shunted non-emergency patients to the clinic
Don't shunt your responsibilities onto your younger colleagues

definitions: close the shutters or protective panels of windows doors or businesses
examples: Residents shuttered their windows before the hurricane arrived
The shop owner shuttered his business for the holiday weekend

definitions: command a dog to attack or chase someone or something aggressively
examples: The guard threatened to sic his dogs on trespassers
Don't sic your pit bull on the mailman

definitions: remove someone from active participation in a game job or activity
examples: The coach sidelined the injured player for three weeks
The scandal sidelined her political career for several years

definitions: put something through a mesh device to separate fine from coarse parts
examples: Sieve the flour before adding it to remove any lumps
The prospector sieved river sand searching for gold particles

definitions: put dry ingredients through a sieve to remove lumps or separate particles
examine something thoroughly and carefully to find what is important
examples: Sift the powdered sugar over the cake for decoration
She sifted flour and baking powder together for the recipe
Detectives sifted through evidence looking for clues to solve the case
Researchers sift through data to identify meaningful patterns

definitions: be a sign or indication of something having particular meaning or importance
make known or express something through words signs or gestures
examples: A red traffic light signifies that drivers must stop
Dark clouds signify that rain is approaching soon
She signified her agreement by nodding her head vigorously
The president signified his approval with an official signature

definitions: mark a route or area with signs giving information or directions
indicate clearly the way something should develop or be understood
examples: The city signposted all tourist attractions for easier navigation
They signposted the hiking trail every half mile
The introduction signposts the main themes of the research paper
Good teachers signpost important concepts during their lectures

definitions: show something as a dark shape or outline against a lighter background
examples: The sunset silhouetted the mountains against the orange sky
The photographer silhouetted the dancers against bright stage lights

definitions: print designs on fabric or paper by forcing ink through a silk mesh
examples: The artist silkscreened posters for the music festival
They silkscreen custom t-shirts for local businesses and events

definitions: become filled or blocked with fine sand mud or clay carried by water
examples: The harbor silted up after decades without proper dredging
Heavy rains cause rivers to silt irrigation channels quickly

definitions: cook food gently in liquid just below boiling point with small bubbles
be in a state of barely suppressed anger or excitement
examples: Simmer the soup for twenty minutes stirring occasionally
The chef simmers tomato sauce all day for rich flavor
Tension simmered between the two rival groups all summer
She simmered with rage but kept her composure during the meeting

definitions: make something easier to do understand or deal with by reducing complexity
examples: The teacher simplified the math problem for younger students
Companies simplify their procedures to improve customer service

definitions: imitate the appearance operation or conditions of something for training or testing
examples: Pilots simulate emergency landings in flight training programs
Scientists simulate climate change effects using computer models

definitions: burn something superficially or lightly typically by accident or to remove unwanted material
examples: He singed his eyebrows while lighting the barbecue grill
The chef singed the duck to remove remaining feathers

definitions: drink something by taking small mouthfuls slowly and carefully
examples: She sipped her hot coffee while reading the morning newspaper
The wine expert sipped each sample before making notes

definitions: draw liquid from one container to another through a tube using pressure
gradually take money or resources dishonestly from an organization
examples: He siphoned gasoline from the car tank into a container
The aquarium keeper siphoned dirty water during tank maintenance
The accountant siphoned company funds into offshore accounts
Corrupt officials siphoned millions from the public works budget

definitions: be the male parent of an animal especially a horse used for breeding
examples: The champion stallion sired over fifty racing horses
This bull has sired prize-winning cattle for ten years

definitions: put something in a particular position or location in relation to surroundings
examples: They decided to situate the new hospital near major highways
The architect situates buildings to maximize natural light exposure
